title: Australian Plate
text:
The Australian Plate is a major <a href="tectonic%20plate">tectonic plate</a> in the <a href="eastern%20hemisphere">eastern</a> and, largely, <a href="southern%20hemisphere">southern</a> hemispheres. Originally a part of the ancient continent of <a href="Gondwana">Gondwana</a>, Australia remained connected to <a href="Indian%20plate">India</a> and <a href="Antarctic%20plate">Antarctica</a> until approximately when India broke away and began moving north. Australia and Antarctica began rifting and completely separated roughly . 
The Australian plate later fused with the adjacent <a href="Indian%20Plate">Indian Plate</a> beneath the <a href="Indian%20Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> to form a single <a href="Indo-Australian%20Plate">Indo-Australian Plate</a>. However, recent studies suggest that the two plates have once again split apart and have been separate plates for at least 3 million years and likely longer. The Australian Plate includes the continent of <a href="Australia%20%28continent%29">Australia</a>, including <a href="Tasmania">Tasmania</a>, as well as portions of <a href="New%20Guinea">New Guinea</a>, <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>, and the <a href="Indian%20Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> basin.
Scope.
The continental crust of this plate covers the whole of Australia, the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Carpentaria">Gulf of Carpentaria</a>, southern <a href="New%20Guinea">New Guinea</a>, the <a href="Arafura%20Sea">Arafura Sea</a>, the <a href="Coral%20Sea">Coral Sea</a>. The continental crust also includes northwestern <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>, <a href="New%20Caledonia">New Caledonia</a> and <a href="Fiji">Fiji</a>. The oceanic crust includes the southeast <a href="Indian%20Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>, the <a href="Tasman%20Sea">Tasman Sea</a>, and the <a href="Timor%20Sea">Timor Sea</a>]. The Australian Plate is bordered (clockwise) by the <a href="Eurasian%20Plate">Eurasian Plate</a>, the <a href="Philippine%20Plate">Philippine Plate</a>, the <a href="Pacific%20Plate">Pacific Plate</a>, the <a href="Antarctic%20Plate">Antarctic Plate</a>, the <a href="African%20Plate">African Plate</a> and the <a href="Indian%20Plate">Indian Plate</a>.
Geography.
The northeasterly side is a complex but generally <a href="convergent%20boundary">convergent boundary</a> with the <a href="Pacific%20Plate">Pacific Plate</a>. The Pacific Plate is subducting under the Australian Plate, which forms the <a href="Tonga%20Trench">Tonga</a> and <a href="Kermadec%20Trench">Kermadec Trench</a>es, and the parallel <a href="Tonga">Tonga</a> and <a href="Kermadec%20Islands">Kermadec</a> <a href="island%20arc">island arc</a>s. It has also uplifted the eastern parts of New Zealand's <a href="North%20Island">North Island</a>.
The continent of <a href="Zealandia%20%28continent%29">Zealandia</a>, which separated from <a href="Australia">Australia</a> 85 million years ago and stretches from <a href="New%20Caledonia">New Caledonia</a> in the north to <a href="New%20Zealand%20Subantarctic%20Islands">New Zealand's subantarctic islands</a> in the south, is now being torn apart along the <a href="transform%20boundary">transform boundary</a> marked by the <a href="Alpine%20Fault">Alpine Fault</a>.
South of New Zealand the boundary becomes a transitional transform-convergent boundary, the <a href="Macquarie%20Fault%20Zone">Macquarie Fault Zone</a>, where the Australian Plate is beginning to subduct under the Pacific Plate along the <a href="Puysegur%20Trench">Puysegur Trench</a>. Extending southwest of this trench is the <a href="Macquarie%20Ridge">Macquarie Ridge</a>.
The southerly side is a <a href="divergent%20boundary">divergent boundary</a> with the <a href="Antarctic%20Plate">Antarctic Plate</a> called the <a href="Southeast%20Indian%20Ridge">Southeast Indian Ridge</a> (SEIR).
The subducting boundary through Indonesia is not parallel to the <a href="biogeography">biogeographical</a> <a href="Wallace%20line">Wallace line</a> that separates the indigenous fauna of Asia from that of <a href="Australasia">Australasia</a>. The eastern islands of Indonesia lie mainly on the <a href="Eurasian%20Plate">Eurasian Plate</a>, but have Australasian-related fauna and flora. Southeasterly lies the <a href="Sunda%20Shelf">Sunda Shelf</a>.
Origins.
Depositional age of the Mount Barren Group on the southern margin of the <a href="Yilgarn%20Craton">Yilgarn Craton</a> and <a href="zircon">zircon</a> provenance analysis support the hypothesis that collisions between the <a href="Pilbara">Pilbara</a>–<a href="Yilgarn%20craton">Yilgarn</a> and <a href="Yilgarn%20craton">Yilgarn</a>–<a href="Gawler">Gawler</a> <a href="Craton">Craton</a>s assembled a proto-Australian continent approximately (Dawson et al. 2002).
